metadata.title: DRIFT study on promotion effects of tungsten-modified Mn/Ce/Ti catalysts for the SCR reaction at low-temperature

Fig. 10 Feature Article DRIFT study on promotion effects of tungsten-modified Mn/Ce/Ti catalysts for the SCR reaction at low-temperature Ki Bok Nam Dong Wook Kwon Sung Chang Hong ⁎ Department of Environmental Energy Engineering, Graduate School of Kyonggi University, 94-6 San, Iui-dong, Youngtong-ku, Suwon-si, Gyeonggi-do 443-760, Republic of Korea Department of Environmental Energy Engineering Graduate School of Kyonggi University 94-6 San Iui-dong Youngtong-ku Suwon-si Gyeonggi-do 443-760 Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The adsorption characteristics of the catalyst surface was studied using FT-IR (DRIFT) to determine the promotion and the causes as W is added through Mn/Ce/Ti and Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts. Addition of W to Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst promotes activity below 200°C. In the FT-IR performed DRIFT test, the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst showed an excellent reaction activity at the SCR reaction when NH3 was introduced; also, compared with the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst, the absorption-acid site of the NH3 increased with a NH4 + that adsorbed to the Brønsted-acid site. Afterward, when NO+O2 was introduced to cause a reaction with the adsorbed NH3, the NH3 adsorbed species quickly decreased at the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst. Next, when the NO+O2 was initially adsorbed, monodentate nitrate, bidentate nitrate, and bridged nitrate adsorbed species were created on the surfaces of the Mn/Ce/W/Ti and Mn/Ce/Ti catalysts. When NH3 was introduced for the reaction, part of the bridged nitrate reacted, but the NO adsorbed species on the catalyst surface were generally less reactive. Therefore, the NO adsorbed on the catalyst surface exhibit a very low reaction activity as compared with the adsorbed NH3. The Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst with the W had the inhibited overall nitrate adsorbed species than the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst. Therefore, the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts increased the low-temperature SCR reaction activity by the increase of the ammonia adsorbent species having excellent reactivity and the decrease of the adsorption of the less reactive nitrogen oxide, compared with the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst. Keywords Mn/Ce/Ti Tungsten Low-temperature SCR NO adspecies DRIFT Surface adsorption 1 Introduction NOx is pollution material that must be removed, as it is the causal material of various environmental-pollution problems such as acid rain, optical chemical smog, and the greenhouse effect. NOx is mainly generated from automobile usage and the use of fossil fuels at a variety of industrial facilities [1,2]. The Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) is known as the most-effective method for the removal of NOx [3]; that is, it is used to decompose NOx into the harmless N2 and H2O through the use of a catalyst after the introduction of NH3, which is a reducing agent for gas that comprises NOx [4], as follows: (1) 4NO+4NH3 +O2 →4N2 +6H2O The catalyst is the most-important technology in the SCR, and generally the V2O5-WO3(MoO3)/TiO2 catalyst is used. But, in the SCR reaction, the relevant catalyst has a very narrow operating temperature (300°C to 400°C) [5,6], it generates N2O at high temperatures, and it problematically volatilizes the active material vanadium [7,8]. The location of the SCR reactor in the existing power plants and industrial facilities causes an activity reduction from the thermal fatigue of the catalyst that is due to frequent changes of the working conditions. Because of this, a spatial restriction exists in the existing process. To increase the life of the catalyst and to secure the installation place, a FGD (flue-gas desulfurization) technology is generally installed in the rear. Due to the power cost of the corresponding re-heating, a huge economic loss that is equivalent to 5% to 10% of the total power of the plant power is generated. In particular, existing industrial boilers do not have space for installing SCR catalyst, and the space for installing SCR after burner has a low temperature range of 160∼200°C. Because of such limitations, the conventional V2O5 based catalyst cannot be used. Accordingly, DeNOx catalyst is required for successful low temperature SCR operation. Catalytic studies have shown an excellent reaction activity at low temperatures through the use of various metallic oxides and the increase of a low SCR activity through the addition of a promoter. Among them, the Mn-series catalysts showed the most-excellent activity at low-temperature SCR reactions. The supported MnOx catalysts include MnOx/Al2O3 [9], MnOx/TiO2 [10], MnOx/CeO2 [11], MnOx-MeOx/TiO2 [12] Mn-doped CeO2/WO3 [13], CeO2-doped MnOx/TiO2 [14,21], and MnOx-CeOx-MeOx/TiO2 [15]. In particular, the studies on the low-temperature SCRs with a high reaction activity for which the Mn and Ce containing catalysts are used are the most active. Manganese oxides are widely used for the active metal of the SCR-catalyst labile oxygen due to the various valence states (Mn2+, Mn3+, and Mn4+) [16]. Ceria is known as an excellent material for its oxygen-storage and oxygen-redox properties according to many studies; this material can store and release oxygen via the redox shift between Ce4+ and Ce3+ under the oxidizing and reducing conditions, respectively [14,27]. It is reported that CeO2-TiO2 based catalysts exhibit excellent NOx conversion, N2 selectivity at mediated-high temperature [28,29]. And, it is also reported that ceria promotes the oxidation of NO into NO2, which results in a low temperature SCR-reaction activity [17,32]. Recently, a study on the increasing of the SCR activity through the addition of tungsten (W) as a promoter to low-temperature SCR reactions was carried out. Particularly, studies on the enhancement of SCR activity by adding tungsten as a promotor to Ce catalyst have been carried out variously [24,30,33]. According to our previous study, W reportedly affected the oxidation value at a catalyst where both manganese (Mn) and ceria (Ce) exist, and it especially increased the Mn4+ and Ce3+ species [17]. Additionally, Shan et al. [18] argued that, if W is added, the active site, oxygen vacancies, and Brønsted and Lewis acid sites would increase. Accordingly, diverse studies on the role of W are carried out. The majority of studies on the low-temperature SCR that involve the achievement of a fast SCR-reaction increase consider the oxidation reaction increase from the surface NO to NO2 as the direct cause of the activity increase [17,19,20]. But the study on the effects of the types of the NO adsorbed species at the catalyst surface with respect to the low-temperature SCR reaction is not extensive. Accordingly, we have investigated Mn-based catalysts, which can be applied to the downstream of FGD or industrial boiler at temperature range of 160∼200°C. In this study, we examined the low-temperature SCR-reaction activity for Mn/Ce/Ti and Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst and its surface adsorption characteristics using in situ diffuse reflectance infrared transform spectroscopy (DRIFT). 2 Experiments 2.1 Preparation method of the catalysts The Mn/Ce/Ti and Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts that were used in this study were produced using the wet-impregnation method. The anatase-type TiO2 (MC-50, Ishiara Sangyo Kaisha, Ltd.), manganese (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Mn(NO3O2∙6H2O, Aldrich Chemical Co.), cerium (III) nitrate, and ammonium metatungstate hydrate ((NH4)6H2W12O40, Aldrich Co.) were used. The calculated amounts of the cerium (III) nitrate (4wt.% Ce) and tungsten (5wt.%W) were immersed in distilled H2O. The slurry was then mixed with a TiO2, ceria, and tungsten solution and stirred for 1h. Then, the moisture was removed at 70°C using an evaporator, while a dry oven at 103°C was used to remove the residual moisture. This support was calcined at 400°C for 4h under an air atmosphere. Then, the manganese (II) nitrate hexahydrate (20wt.% Mn) was calculated based on the manufactured support and melted into distilled water. After the impregnation of the Mn solution into the Ce/Ti or Ce/W/Ti supports, the moisture was removed using the 70°C evaporator and the 103°C dry oven. The catalysts were calcined in air for 4h at 400°C. 2.2 Catalytic-activity test The SCR activity measurements were carried out in a fixed-bed quartz reactor (inner diameter=8mm). Mass-flow controllers (MKS Co.) were used to set the NO, NH3, O2, and N2 feeds. The reactant-gas composition is as follows: 200ppm NO, 200ppm NH3, 8 vol% O2, and 8 vol% H2O in N2. H2O was fed into the reactor by injecting N2 containing water vapor through the bubbler, and this level of water was maintained constant by circulating water at a fixed temperature of 45°C using a circulator outside the jacket-type bubbler. The entire gas supply line of stainless steel and was wrapped with a heating band set to 180°C so that the water would not condense. For each test, 0.6g of the catalyst (40mesh to 50mesh, 1.2 cc) was used. The feed-flow rate that was fixed at 600 cc/min corresponds to the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 30,000h−1. The compositions of the inlet and outlet were monitored continuously online using non-dispersive infrared gas analyzers (ZKJ-2 for NO/NO2, Fuji Electric Co.; and Ultramat 6 for N2O, Siemens Co.). The moisture was removed from all of the gases through the chiller before they were analyzed. The NOx conversion and N2 selectivity was calculated from the concentrations of the gases at the steady state according to the following equations: (2) NO x conversion ( % ) = [ NO ] in − [ NO + NO 2 ] out [ NO ] in × 100 (3) N 2 selectivity ( % ) = ( [ NO ] in + [ NH 3 ] in ) − [ NO 2 ] out − 2 [ N 2 O ] out [ NO ] in + [ NH 3 ] in × 100 2.3 In situ DRIFT studies This study used an in situ DRIFT analysis that was performed with an FT-IR (Nicolet iS10, Thermo Co.). A DR (diffuse reflectance) 400 accessory was used for the analysis of the solid reflectance. The CaF2 window was used as a plate for the DR measurement, and the spectra were collected using an MCT (mercury cadmium telluride) detector. All of the catalysts that were used for this analysis were ground using a rod in the sample pan of an in situ chamber with an installed temperature controller. To prevent the influence of moisture and other adsorbents, the sample was pretreated with N2 gas at a rate of 100 cc/min under 300°C for 1h. Then, the spectra of the catalyst were collected by measuring the single-beam spectrum of the preprocessed sample as the background, and all of the analyses were performed using auto-scanning at a resolution of 4cm−1. The absorbance-IR spectra were recorded using the Nicolet Nexus spectrometer (Model Magna IR 550 II) equipped with a liquid-nitrogen-cooled MCT detector, and 32 scans with a spectral resolution of 4cm−1 were collected. 2.4 Temperature-programmed desorption (NO-TPD, NH3-TPD, NO+NH3-TPD) A temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) was carried out to analyze the NO and NH3 adsorption capacity of the catalyst. This measurement was carried out using 0.3g samples of the catalysts. Prior to the TPD measurements, the catalysts were pretreated at 300°C for 30min while they were in a 5% O2/He flow of 50 cc/min. After they were chilled to 50°C, the samples were treated with target gas (1% NO/Ar or 1% NH3/Ar) for 1h. Before the TPD experiments, the NO or NH3 was purged for 1h with Ar. During the TPD experiments, the quantities of the NO, NO2, and NH3 (NOm/e 30, NO2 m/e 46, NH3 m/e 15) were monitored continuously using a quadrupole mass spectrometer (QMS 422), while the temperature was increased to 600°C at a rate of 10°C/min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity The effect of W on the selective catalytic-reduction activity of the Mn/Ce/Ti catalysts was evaluated. As shown in Fig. 1 ., the NOx conversion activity was determined using the Mn/Ce/Ti and Mn/Ce/W/Ti from 120°C to 200°C and a GHSV of 30,000h−1. The activity of the Mn/Ce/Ti is 86% at 160°C. The addition of W to the Mn/Ce/Ti system remarkably increased the activity by 5% to 25% at the temperature of 180°C or lower; furthermore, the W addition could enhance the low-temperature SCR activity of the Mn/Ce/Ti catalysts and broaden the temperature window for the NOx conversion. Mn/Ce/Ti, Mn/Ce/W/Ti produced N2O at 5ppm or less over the entire temperature range and showed excellent N2 selectivity of 95% or more. 3.2 DRIFT studies 3.2.1 NH3 adsorption In the preceding studies, the addition of W affected the increase of the NH3 adsorption [17]. While the preceding studies studied the NH3 adsorption amount only, a study on the adsorption type and the adsorption site of NH3 has not been conducted; thus, this study analyzed the NH3-adsorbed species type regarding the surface of the catalyst. The NH3 adsorption species on the Mn/Ce/Ti and the Mn/Ce/W/Ti at various temperatures were investigated using FT-IR spectroscopy. Before the NH3 adsorption, the samples were pre-treated at 300°C in N2 for 1h to remove the other adsorbed species. After the samples were cooled to the specified adsorption temperature (at 50°C, 120°C, and 160°C), 1000ppm of NH3 was introduced. According to Fig. 2 ., all of the adsorbed species were found at the Lewis and Brønsted acid sites for the Mn/Ce/Ti and Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts. The peaks were generated according to the wave number (cm−1), and the detected NH3 adsorption peaks are at 966cm−1, 1180cm−1, 1438cm−1, 1532cm−1, 1600cm−1, 3143cm−1, 3245cm−1, and 3377cm−1. The peak that was generated at 966cm−1 is the weak adsorption NH3 or the gaseous NH3 [24]. The bands at 1180cm−1 and 1600cm−1 can be assigned to the asymmetric bending vibration of the NH bond in the NH3 that is coordinately linked to the Lewis-acid site [25]. The peaks that were generated at 1438cm−1 and 1532cm−1 show that the NH4 +combined with the Brønsted acid site or an asymmetry in the form of the NH bond NH3 + group [25]. The peaks that were detected at 3143cm−1, 3254cm−1, and 3377cm−1 show that the species of (Vs(NH3)) and (Vas(NH3) combined with the Lewis acid site [24]. An analysis of the NH3 adsorption type by temperature, if the NH3 is adsorbed at 50°C, shows no apparent difference between the Mn/Ce/Ti and the Mn/Ce/W/Ti. When the adsorption temperature of the NH3 was increased, all of the bands became weaker. But, while the NH4 + species that absorbed to the Mn/Ce/Ti and Brønsted-acid sites almost disappeared at 160°C, the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst with the W partially maintained the peak of the Brønsted-acid site at 160°C. Accordingly, the W addition to the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst promoted the Brønsted acid site of the NH3 surface, and it increased the thermal stability of the generated Brønsted acid sites. In addition, the adsorption characteristics of NH3 could be confirmed by NH3-TPD in Fig. 3 (a). The adsorption temperature of NH3 was carried out at 160°C, which showed the greatest difference on DRIFT. Experimental results showed that NH3 adsorption was increased in Mn/Ce/W/Ti compared with Mn/Ce/Ti. In addition, NO signal was measured for NH3-TPD experiment to confirm that the adsorbed ammonia on the catalyst surface was oxidized to NO when desorbed (Fig. 3(b)). In other words, it was confirmed that Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst generated more NO than Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst. If the ammonia adsorbed in the SCR reaction was oxidized without reaction with NO, the ammonia acted as a reducing agent in the SCR reaction was deficient. As a result, the SCR reaction activity was decreased. In addition, NO produced by NH3 oxidation decreases SCR activity because it increases exit NO production. Thus, W enhanced the thermal stability of the adsorbed ammonia and inhibited generation of NO over the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst. As a result, it was considered that NH3 participated in the SCR reaction was increased. Therefore, it promoted the low-temperature SCR activity. 3.2.2 Reaction between nitrogen oxides and ammonia ad-species The catalysts were pre-exposed to the NH3 for 30min, and this was followed by an N2 purging for 30min at 160°C. NO + O2/N2 was then introduced into the IR cell at 160°C, and the spectra were recorded as a function of time. According to Fig. 4 ., the coordinated-NH3 species (1600cm−1, 3143cm−1, 3245cm−1, and 3377cm−1) and the NH4 + species (1438cm−1 and 1535cm−1) formed on the Mn/Ce/Ti and the Mn/Ce/W/Ti upon the treatment with the NH3. After the NO+O2 was introduced into the cell, all of the NH3-adsorption species decreased. In Fig. 4(b), after 400s of reaction time, the peaks of the NH3 and NH4 + decreased at the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst; whereas, in Fig. 4 (a), the NH3 peaks continued for 3143cm−1, 3245cm−1, and 3377cm−1 after 400s of reaction time at the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst. All of the peaks disappeared after 700s. Compared with the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst, the bands that correspond to the adsorbed NH3 species decreased more quickly on the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst (Fig. 4(b)). Accordingly, it can be confirmed that NH3 adsorbed on the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst exhibits increased reactivity. And, if the NH3 peak was no longer observable, it showed that the peak increased to 1607cm−1 from 1582cm−1. Along with the introduction of the NO + O2, the adsorbed NH3 were all reacted and then exhausted, resulting in the creation of the NO adsorbed species. The relevant adsorbed species will be explained in detail in the next clause. 3.2.3 Co-adsorption for NO and O2 Generally, the SCR is explained by two mechanisms. The first mechanism is the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism suggested by Otto et al. [22,26]. In this mechanism, it is argued that the reaction between the adsorbed NH3(ad) and the adsorbed NO(ad) is mutual for the SCR. The second mechanism, argued by Miyamoto et al. [23,26], involves the adsorbed NH4 + (ad) responding to the catalyst with gaseous NO(g) at over 100°C, and is the Eley-Rideal mechanism. The main difference between the two mechanisms is the NO species type in the reaction. Thus, this study investigated the type of NO species that participates in the reaction to survey the change of the SCR mechanism according to the addition of W. Studies on the SCR reaction activity according to the type of NO adsorbed species have been actively carried out. Jiang et al. [12] and Liu et al. [15] argued that specific NO adsorbed species are increased by the addition of Ca and Fe promoters, and therefore the adsorption amount and the adsorption type of the NO directly affect the SCR reaction. As such, diverse studies are carried out on the SCR reaction activity according to the type of the NO adsorption. To determine the main reaction mechanism of the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst, the NO adsorbed species on the Mn/Ce/Ti and Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts were investigated using FT-IR spectroscopy. Before the NO adsorption, the samples were treated at 300°C in N2 for 30min to remove any adsorbed species. After the samples were cooled to 160°C (temperature with the most efficient difference), 1000ppm of NO and 3% O2 were applied on the Mn/Ce/Ti and Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts at the same temperature, as shown in Fig. 5 . The bands at 1240cm−1, 1284cm−1, 1338cm−1, 1487cm−1, 1582cm−1, 1607cm−1, and 1620cm−1 were observed. The bands at 1240cm−1 and 1607cm−1 could be attributed to the bridged nitrate [12]. The bands at 1284cm−1 and 1487cm−1 can be assigned to the monodentate nitrate [24]. The band at 1582cm−1 might be assigned to the bidentate nitrate [24]. The band at 1620cm−1 could be assigned to the asymmetric frequency of the gaseous NO2 molecules. The negative band at 1338cm−1 could be associated with the consumption of the isolated surface −OH groups; as for the cause of the decrease of such surface −OH species, Jiang et al. [12] suggested that the O2 could promote the dehydration reaction of the Mn oxides to produce active O2, and this greatly enhances the amounts of the NO complexes on the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 5(a), the NO adsorbed species at (a) the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst showed the bridged nitrate species and the bidentate nitrate species at 1607cm−1 and 1582cm−1, respectively, and if NO is introduced, the increasing of the bands would continue. And, the decrease of the −OH species at 1338cm−1 was also detected. In Fig. 5(b), the type of adsorbed species that was detected is the same as the NO adsorbed species that was detected at the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst; but, the size of the created peak is relatively small, and the decrease of the −OH at 1338cm−1 is relatively very small. To the contrary, a gaseous NO2 band, which was not detected at the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst, was created at 1620cm−1. Such NO adsorption characteristics are verified through the NO-TPD in Fig. 6 . In the first place, the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst of Fig. 6(a) shows a relatively smaller NO desorption peak than the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst. Together with the DRIFT experiment, such a result shows that the NO adsorbed species decreased at the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst with the addition of W. As shown in Fig. 6(b), it was confirmed that the NO2 desorption increased at low temperatures lower than 200°C at the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst. Accordingly, the addition of W tends to inhibit the creation of the NO adsorbed species at the catalyst surface, and it also decreases the adsorption strength; furthermore, it exerted an effect on the increasing of the NO2 generation at the catalyst surface. In particular, for the generated NO2, it is an important influence factor in the increasing of the low-temperature SCR reaction activity through its promotion of a fast SCR reaction at the catalyst reaction [17]; accordingly, the addition of W would impact on the SCR reaction activity by increasing the fast SCR and decreasing the overall NO adsorbed species. 3.2.4 Reaction between ammonia and nitrogen oxide ad-species In this experiment, the Mn/Ce/Ti and Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts were first treated with NO+O2/N2 for 30min, and the NO was shut down accompanied by the simultaneous introduction of NH3+O2/N2. The DRIFT spectra were measured by time, which is shown in Fig. 7 . According to Fig. 7(a), when the NH3+O2/N2 passed over the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst, some changes were observed. The bands at 1607cm−1 and 1240cm−1 that are due to the absorbed bridged nitrate declined; however, for the bidentate nitrate species from 1580cm−1 to 1560cm−1 and the monodentate nitrate species at 1284cm−1, there was no peak decrease when the NH3 was introduced at 160°C. Accordingly, the monodentate nitrate and bidentate nitrate-adsorbed species did not react with the NH3 at 160°C. To the contrary, among the NO adsorbed species, the bridged nitrate adsorbed species showed an excellent activity with the NH3 at the relevant temperature (160°C) compared with the monodentate nitrate and the bidentate nitrate. Hu et al. [31] suggests that bridged nitrate was an NO adsorbent species that exhibits a more active SCR reaction activity than monodentate nitrate and bidentate nitrate. Likewise, at the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst (Fig. 7(b)), the bridged nitrate adsorbed species at 1607cm−1 and 1240cm−1 decreased, but the monodentate nitrate and the bidentate nitrate did not reactions relatively. After a 200s reaction, if there was no further decrease or change of the NO peak, the band that originated from the NH3 adspecies began to grow. At 3351cm−1, 3271cm−1, 3613cm−1, and 1607cm−1, the NH3 that had adsorbed to the Lewis acid site and the NH4 + that had adsorbed to the Brønsted acid site, and that were detected at 1432cm−1 began to form. Accordingly, the NO adsorbed species that can react with the NO adsorbed species that had adsorbed on the surface had all reacted. To analyze the characteristics of the NO adsorbed species that existed on the surface of the catalyst without a reaction, the NO desorption DRIFT test was carried out, the results of which are shown in Fig. 8 . The test method for Fig. 8 is the same as the method that was used for Fig. 5. The results show the adsorption of the NO+O2. After the purged at each temperature for 30min with the N2 gas and without the introduction of the NO+O2, the surface adsorption status was checked. As shown in Fig. 8(a), no desorption was found at the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst up to 200°C, and the bridged nitrate and bidentate nitrate were detected at 1607cm−1 and 1582cm−1, respectively. The above NO adsorbed species disappeared above 270°C. But, in Fig. 8(b), the bands (1607cm−1 and 1582cm−1) of the bridged nitrate and bidentate nitrate at the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst disappeared below 200°C; such band changes showed an easier desorption when the W was added to the NO adspecies on the surface. In the NO-TPD test, more NO desorption peaks were shown at the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst above 200°C. It seems that the relevant bands that were found using the FT-IR are those of the bridged-nitrate and bidentate-nitrate species (Fig. 6). In order to confirm the effect of adsorbed NO for NH3 adsorption on the surface of the catalyst, NO and NH3 were adsorbed continuously to perform TPD experiment (NO + NH3-TPD). The pretreatment of the catalyst was carried out in the same mathod as the NO-TPD and the NH3-TPD performed previously, and 1% NO/Ar gas was injected for 1h and adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst. Then, the injection of NO is stopped and the catalyst is adsorbed on the catalyst surface for 1h by using 1% NH3/Ar gas continuously. Next, Ar was injected in the same method as the above-mentioned TPD experiment, and the temperature was raised to 800°C, and the desorbed gas was measured. As shown in Fig. 9 (a), (b), the change in the adsorption characteristics of ammonia can be confirmed. In the NH3-TPD experiment using only ammonia in Fig. 9., desorption of ammonia was observed at around 100–200°C and 300°C, but NO + NH3-TPD experiment that adsorbed ammonia on the NO adsorbed surface, the ammonia desorption peak at 300°C decreased. From these results, it can be seen that the adsorption sites of ammonia and NO are partially shared by the two catalysts (Mn/Ce/Ti, Mn/Ce/W/Ti). Therefore, when NO rather than NH3 is adsorbed to the same adsorption site, the SCR efficiency may be reduced due to low reactivity. Thus, the addition of W was determining that weaken the adsorption of NO adsorbed complexes in addition to inhibiting the formation of NO complex. For this reason, adsorption amount of NH3 increased instead of NO adsorption on shared adsorption sites. As a result, the catalyst activity increases in low-temperature SCR [12,24]. 3.2.5 DRIFT spectra in a flow of NO+NH3 +O2 To confirm the species that were present on the catalysts under the reaction condition, the DRIFT spectra were recorded at the reaction temperature of 160°C in a flow of NO + NH3 + O2. As shown in Fig. 10 (a), the bands that are due to the various ad species were observed at 1607cm−1, 1560cm−1, 1432cm−1, 1284cm−1, and 1240cm−1 at 160°C on the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst. The 1603cm−1 peak might be caused by the overlapping of the bands of the bridged nitrate and the coordinated NH3 on the Lewis acid site [24]. In the region of 3000cm−1 to 4000cm−1, there are NH stretching bands. Regarding the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst, the various adspecies were observed at 1607cm−1, 1556cm−1, 1438cm−1, and 1240cm−1 at 160°C. The 1607cm−1 peak might be caused by the overlapping of the bands of the bridged nitrate and the coordinated NH3 on the Lewis-acid site, like the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst [24]. In the region of 3000cm−1 to 4000cm−1, the two catalysts showed the same type of NH3-adsorption peak. There are two differences between the adsorption-peak types of the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst (Fig. 10(a)) and the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst (Fig. 10(b)). First, the monodentate nitrate and bridged nitrate peaks were detected at 1284cm−1 and 1240cm−1 respectively, for the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst but the monodentate nitrate peak which is 1284cm−1 was not detected for the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst. A peak that is relatively very small was detected for the bridged nitrate at 1240cm−1. The second difference is that a very high intensity NH4 + peak of 1432cm−1 was found for the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst compared with the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst on the Brønsted acid site. Accordingly, relatively more NH4 + species were adsorbed to the surface at the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst compared with the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst. This result is the same as the result of the FT IR step test in the previous clause. Accordingly, the following results can be discerned. (1) In the SCR reaction process, the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst showed a greater adsorption of the NH4 + type of NH3 than the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst. (2) The addition of W decreased the NO complexes in the reaction characteristics of the catalyst. Especially in the presence of ammonia, inhibited the production of monodentate nitrate, which is low SCR activity. 4 Conclusions This study examined the catalyst-surface adsorption characteristics using the DRIFT analysis to determine the effect of the addition of W to the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst at the low-temperature SCR. The main conclusions that were drawn are as follows: (1) The addition of W to the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst affected the surface-adsorption types of the NH3 and NOx. At first, the NH3 adsorption promoted when the W was added. In particular, the W made thermal stability of the Brønsted-acid site increase. And it promoted the reaction activity of NH3 adsorption species. (2) According to the DRIFT analysis, the NO(ad) adsorbed the catalyst surface was existed in three types; Monodentate nitrate, bidentate nitrate, and bridged nitrate. Among them, the NO adspecies adsorbed to the monodentate nitrate or the bidentate nitrate showed a very low reaction in the low-temperature SCR. Particularly, the adsorption amount of NO decreased in the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst and the formation of the NO complex which had a low reactivity was inhibited. (3) The adsorption sites of NH3 and NO were partially shared in Mn/Ce/Ti and Mn/Ce/W/Ti. This adsorption sites were considered that adsorption of NH3 was increased and adsorption of NO was decreased in Mn/Ce/W/Ti. Therefore, addition of W affeceted that the activity of the low-temperature SCR reaction was increased by the increase of NH3 adsorption amount, reactivity and the inhibition of NO adsorption. In addition, it suggested that the reaction mechanism was changed compared to the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst due to the change of adsorption characteristics of Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst. (4) The addition, the introduction of W will promote the conversion of gaseous NO to NO2, therefore pomting “fast SCR” reaction to promote low temperature SCR activity. coredata.dc:description: The adsorption characteristics of the catalyst surface was studied using FT-IR (DRIFT) to determine the promotion and the causes as W is added through Mn/Ce/Ti and Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts. Addition of W to Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst promotes activity below 200°C. In the FT-IR performed DRIFT test, the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst showed an excellent reaction activity at the SCR reaction when NH3 was introduced; also, compared with the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst, the absorption-acid site of the NH3 increased with a NH4 + that adsorbed to the Brønsted-acid site. Afterward, when NO+O2 was introduced to cause a reaction with the adsorbed NH3, the NH3 adsorbed species quickly decreased at the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst. Next, when the NO+O2 was initially adsorbed, monodentate nitrate, bidentate nitrate, and bridged nitrate adsorbed species were created on the surfaces of the Mn/Ce/W/Ti and Mn/Ce/Ti catalysts. When NH3 was introduced for the reaction, part of the bridged nitrate reacted, but the NO adsorbed species on the catalyst surface were generally less reactive. Therefore, the NO adsorbed on the catalyst surface exhibit a very low reaction activity as compared with the adsorbed NH3. The Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalyst with the W had the inhibited overall nitrate adsorbed species than the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst. Therefore, the Mn/Ce/W/Ti catalysts increased the low-temperature SCR reaction activity by the increase of the ammonia adsorbent species having excellent reactivity and the decrease of the adsorption of the less reactive nitrogen oxide, compared with the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: DRIFT study on promotion effects of tungsten-modified Mn/Ce/Ti catalysts for the SCR reaction at low-temperature
